head.title: Moms and Dads, at Work and at Home

hedline.hl1: Moms and Dads, at Work and at Home

block.p: You report that families in which both parents work have now edged into a 51 percent majority of married couples with children (news article, Oct. 24). What is surprising is not that it has happened, but that it has only just happened.

You report that families in which both parents work have now edged into a 51 percent majority of married couples with children (news article, Oct. 24). What is surprising is not that it has happened, but that it has only just happened.

For years the politically correct rhetoric in areas as diverse as family law and television advertising has been that two working parents are the normative structure. But working-mother hype overlooks the flip side of the numbers: nonworking mothers are an amazingly large group.

Stay-at-home mothers have been marginalized by assumptions that overlook them and proclamations celebrating the number of working mothers. Now that they have become a minority, let's not discount them entirely.
CYNTHIA LEE STARNES East Lansing, Mich., Oct. 24, 2000
The writer is a professor of family law at Michigan State University.
